You should realize that when it comes to our (US) politics and elections, very rarely do we get to choose somebody who we agree with on every single issue. Especially at the executive level (the President). So we have to choose out of those offered who we agree with on most issues, or who we think will move in the right direction in general. Kinda like trying to choose the person who will result in two steps forward, one back, instead of the opposite.

I'm not suggesting we need more options, 'cause that results in a far worse problem. Namely that a vast majority of people may be split and therefore a small minority succeeds in what the majority absolutely didn't want. (Suppose 74% of the people would accept option 1, 2, or 3, but absolutely would never want option 4. But due to preferences on certain details, the 74% are split evenly among the first three. Now option 4 that 74% totally oppose gets chosen because 26% were united on that one. Yikes!)

A society's institutions reflect the values of that society. For example, in Greece most drugs are not restricted very harshly, however they have very severe laws against hash. [hr]LevelLord Quite frankly, I'd like to quote the late Reverend Burnside: 'To hell with morals and the preachers of the chains of control be dammed! When every man does what he knows is right then we will have no church, God will be in the streets.'
[hr]Amen to that.

As far as I can see there are no absolutes when it comes to morality. However, there are benefits for doing what you know is right, rather than what you think will get you what you want. We bring about our own undoing when we set in motion schemes to bring down our fellow humans in the name of our own insecurities.

Let me offer another way of looking at right and wrong, just and unjust. One of the most fundamental things most self-help and spiritual teachers will tell you is that we are each responsible for our own reality, that our thoughts bring to us the events and circumstances of our lives.

This poses more questions than it answers, though. Why are some born better off than others if the playing ground is so even? The most suitable explanation I can offer is that we, as our souls, rather than the shells we inhabit, determine what happens in our lives. In our current state, these decisions are made unconsciously for the most part, and thus very indirectly and haphazardly.

I have earned a fair degree of control over my reality to date, and having seen what thought is capable of I firmly believe in that we are indeed fully responsible for our lives.

I do not have anything more, as far as personal experience goes, than a string of encounters with what may or may not be spirits of those who have gone before (and some who claim not to have) to go on as to whether or not there is anything at all after death, let alone reincarnation. Nonetheless, the foregoing conclusion infers this, or something very similar, must be how it works.Cave assectatorem Ductoris Alacris

The development of the hardware, and the greater ability to express every idea that flies into a programmers head, mean that game creators have made the new games congested with every technique in their power. The basic games behind all this are so blurred that people cant catch up. We should go back to basics like Pac-Man and play in an easier, more relaxed way. -Toru Iwatani
